562C0058F60C4024838FBDE39C8FD47A.description: Propose an answer to a question or problem related to the importance of air and water for living things.

AF2F9C51F04B4A03A75660C1F6457697.description: Suggest ways that individuals can contribute to protecting and improving the quality of air and water in their environment (e.g., conserving water, not pouring chemicals down the drain, not burning hazardous materials, and reducing travel via motorized vehicles).

A5B2B06E77334B82809FE5445BC6211A.description: Suggest explanations for how air and water in the environment can become polluted.

12756B7BBCEB4AC287382B95C14E2702.description: Record, using tables, diagrams, pictographs, or bar graphs, individual, classroom, and/or household use of water for a given period.

0B08ADE44DCD4A87850D1D29086411A2.description: Communicate questions, ideas, and intentions while conducting personal and group explorations of air and water in the environment.

C18BB549EC4C4369835DFCD3FE6DCE0D.description: Explain how water is obtained, distributed, and used in personal, local, and regional environments (e.g., home, classroom, school, town, city, and province).

29C6DA340F704678B99E52B8CD22BEC8.description: Explain how living things, including humans, require clean air and water for breathing, cooling, drinking, cooking, bathing, and prevention of illness to maintain a healthy body.

434EEB9F420D4B3B99F5EE6956BA0B6E.description: Recognize the importance of air and water as two of the four elements (i.e., air, water, earth, fire) in Mother Earth in First Nations, Métis, and other cultures.

62258CBAAB3D45C99AE921244BB80265.description: Describe changes in the location, amount, and form of moisture in different locations in the environment, and factors such as exposure to heat and moving air that can affect these conditions.

EEF1EFC6B2B740F39CA21BB7A5689A51.description: Pose questions that lead to exploration and investigation about air and water conditions (e.g., Why does skin feel wet in the summer? Why is it harder to breathe in winter than in summer? Why might people wear a filter over their nose and mouth?).

12C2D68558344CC18F3B0B571E002572.description: Assess the importance of air and water for the health and survival of living things, including self, and the environment.

56DB4B0F83B44C11B6FBF25AB3A2FC63.description: Communicate procedures and results of observations of the physical properties of air and water, using drawings, demonstrations, and written and oral descriptions.

8193525A6E8745FB83E0885C477E091E.description: Classify or sequence materials according to attributes such as how quickly they absorb water, how much water they absorb, and whether they are waterproof or water repellent.

A4BD20AA384040A2BB9E2C2B1F368298.description: Collaboratively design and construct a device that is powered by wind or water and that meets a student-identified purpose

7D81944144254FE3A9EE9FD1B7D4FC1F.description: Carry out procedures to investigate methods of increasing or decreasing the rate water changes state (i.e., freezing or boiling).

4F1711CB087F4939A3B0DDECD365DC5E.description: Investigate physical (e.g., mass, shape, texture, colour, and odour) changes in water during each change of state (i.e., freezing, melting, evaporation, condensation, sublimation, and deposition).

9FA61884504342549E84B295493FE87C.description: Categorize examples of water in indoor and outdoor environments, and in living things, including themselves, according to state of matter (i.e., solid, liquid, and gaseous).

37432D57DF364755BAAC8631FE58681A.description: Provide evidence indicating air takes up space, has mass, and can be felt when it moves.

CA99EB48F24747C7A8FC18C211BB40C6.description: Measure amounts of air and water using non-standard measurements (e.g., dropper, spoonful, container, pop bottle, garbage can, aquarium, straw, and zip-lock bag).

609DADA6E4444295B193ABC584DB9C84.description: Select appropriate tools (e.g., thermometer, wind sock, rain gauge, garden hose, fan, oar, propeller, and vacuum) and materials to carry out safely their own explorations of air and water in their environment through processes such as collecting dew, rainfall, and snow; measuring wind speed; and measuring temperature.

0C4016332B164383AE2C68311176AF6D.description: Observe, using all of their senses, physical properties of air (e.g., generally invisible, odourless, and fills and assumes shape of container) and of water (e.g., assumes shape of container, clear, tasteless, and odourless).

AC21819922144623B2107C8AAD82BDBB.description: Investigate properties of air and water (in all three states of matter) within their environment.

B688C2FA482B41CC847382A97CB1F39B.description: Physical Science: Air and Water in the Environment (AW)

4286A06E92A44A55AA6CAB2F64B55F9E.description: Generate new questions about the motion of objects that arise from what was learned (e.g., Do objects move the same way in space or in water or in another liquid? What causes motion?).

8D7EAFCEF29D46C8B9385D1DB7BE2E35.description: Provide examples of technologies (e.g., skate, snowshoe, bicycle, ski, kayak, curling slider, and wheelchair) that are designed to make it easier for people and constructed objects to move on different surfaces.

D9FE5909773E4D138D4C5057606EF930.description: Observe and record the effects of different textured surfaces on the friction between two objects or surfaces.

EC219DA82D4D4BB6B11FF6F60022E90A.description: Carry out a procedure to investigate the effects of pushes and pulls on the motion of objects using various objects and surfaces (e.g., paper, carpet, sandpaper, desktop, tile floor, wooden board, ice, sidewalk, grass, soil, and sand).

16129D514954428CB4ED8F8C56FBC1C8.description: Describe the movement of a specified object using appropriate vocabulary so that other students can duplicate the movement.

6167848532E542D1BB0E5A463E0ED1B7.description: Demonstrate how pushes and pulls can cause an object to speed up, slow down, stop, or change direction.

8C168D7E28424647B281A1BFE9284903.description: Relate the types of motion (e.g., crawling, walking, running, flying, swimming, slithering, galloping, crab walking, and rolling) to the physical characteristics of humans and familiar animals.

57D9D513C6084C60984246E3DD805A87.description: Investigate, describe, and represent different patterns of movement (e.g., walking, running, swinging, bouncing, sliding, rotating, spinning, crawling, and rolling) of familiar objects, including themselves.

97E02FBE6A1E457DA5580FF8A0D9B098.description: Examine a variety of toys, playground equipment, and other objects that move or which have components that move and ask questions that lead to exploration and investigation of the motion of objects.

4174E5FAD39141E592FE298E6A6B7B18.description: Describe the motion of an object in terms of a change in position relative to other objects (e.g., faster, slower, towards, away, closer, and further).

3BED9B8CE8EF4C1F90E1D74C3F9FA2E9.description: Describe examples of the motion of natural (e.g., birds flying, leaves falling, tree branches swaying, icicles melting, fish swimming, wind blowing, and creeks flowing) and constructed (e.g., vehicles moving, clock hands rotating, balls bouncing, playground swings, and tools operating) objects in their environment.

B9C66802D0754C859216AD94D81C9262.description: Pose questions about the motion of natural and constructed objects in their environment (e.g., How do we know if something is moving? What are some different types of motion? Why is it difficult to walk on some surfaces?).

A5122038A51C44A2B8C420D00E2BC4B4.description: Investigate factors, including friction, which affect the motion of natural and constructed objects, including self.

F0BB2A2A7CFE422F8941732890C72784.description: Follow directions to move in a specified way to different positions.

6F769CA9958A4E14B27344BD0285F40D.description: Create a set of directions (e.g., treasure hunt map) that other students can follow to locate a specified position.

CD4357763A4941DD9060A867FD3F0133.description: Explore how changing one’s own position affects one’s perspective of position relative to self and other objects.

CD92A412535A4F1883D710E34C153EDD.description: Collaborate with other students to describe the position of an object from different positions using drawings, and written and oral descriptions.

6F0A9825A9BC49678BA35D88CB50DCAD.description: Represent the position of objects as seen from different perspectives (e.g., top, side, and bottom) using words, diagrams, and actions.

E6F0EAF69007426F86AD144CB0510D77.description: Record observations and measurements of an object’s position, using oral and written language, diagrams, and tables.

D815E8D8F4F74E4CAE6CE8C3385E52EF.description: Use appropriate tools (e.g., rulers and string) safely for observing and recording objects’ positions.

A4B3B7C95D3A42A4A132335E94490759.description: Assess the use of common objects (e.g., hand, step, and book) to describe the position of an object using non-standard units.

5C13A2056E0642C081C72016BD0787E8.description: Place an object in an identified position (e.g., four steps to the right and one step forward, close, far, right, left, forward, back, up, down) relative to another object or position

EDC6F70440FD48A785A31C9A43D50EED.description: Describe the position of an object relative to other positions or stationary objects, including themselves, using appropriate vocabulary such as above, below, between, beside, on top, close to, far from, behind, in front of, to the right of, and to the left of.

A889387F09E6464AA731CDB196FED7E0.description: Analyze methods of determining the position of objects relative to other objects.

4E57BBA849C249EB8B2527C63B8C8E44.description: Physical Science: Motion and Relative Position (MP)

595DBA0899984504BD09B98C8D6CCA78.description: Assess ways people use knowledge of solids and liquids to maintain a clean and healthy environment (e.g., filtering water, sorting solids for recycling, cleaning up a kitchen spill, washing dishes, cleaning paint brushes, using hand cleaners, wearing a paint smock).

62617580050F428AB909C6A9453E2259.description: Demonstrate an understanding of sinking and floating by solving a related practical problem such as building an object that will float, carry a load, and be stable.

5554B12FA9F04F8294125425F962F48C.description: Use a variety of sources (e.g., newspapers, Elders, anglers, books, videos, and Internet) to gather information about objects that sink and float (e.g., canoes, kayaks, barges, boats, buoys, and fishing lures).

4DB7545465C8412A885FF998DE64B255.description: Design and carry out an investigation to determine the rate and ability of various materials (e.g., paper, paper towel, cotton, plastic, and wax paper) to absorb liquids and explain how these capabilities determine their uses.

E59CBBF6B69A4443A18D29EDE3C15ADF.description: Carry out an investigation to determine the relative viscosity of different liquids (e.g., water, milk, and syrup) when placed on various surfaces (e.g., paper, paper towel, cotton, plastic, and wax paper)

68FAA1505AD848D488CB1C22C10EF237.description: Distinguish between familiar solids (e.g., sand, sugar, salt, gravel, soil, and drink crystals) that dissolve in water and those that do not

A0D3F8A270E14CD6BEF861849AF05F6F.description: Investigate and describe the changes in characteristics of familiar solids and liquids resulting from processes such as mixing and dissolving liquids with liquids, solids with solids, and liquids with solids.

58F569730DAF468AAB33150BF07AADC1.description: Describe examples of useful objects and materials in their environment that are made by combining different liquids or solids and liquids.

34966D247BE94751943B82DDDD78D0F6.description: Investigate how liquids change when they are poured into different containers.

1286338BC12846479F11034F6E5841FF.description: Pose questions that lead to exploration and investigation of combining liquids and solids.

1E0A6397F1A14D23A9E26CE814A63A10.description: Investigate interactions between liquids and solids, and technologies based on those interactions

CB3E47089636460A92CBFA75F98FA176.description: Predict and test changes in characteristics (e.g., shape, colour, and volume) of liquids when they are changed into solids or gases.

B5301A23BAC14AFBB736413E96187209.description: Group or sequence liquids and solids according to one or more observable physical properties (e.g., colour, state, texture, smell, transparency, and buoyancy).

DD08C33FD97649F2A2CBA135E5244C12.description: Investigate to determine whether properties of familiar liquids and solids depend on factors such as the amount of substance present.

7C06791B2B6C42E0A11E6B598052BE24.description: Demonstrate that liquids and solids are matter because they have mass and take up space.

91187669316F4CC3A98B17871B165704.description: Distinguish between properties of familiar liquids and solids.

2BDFF7D1ADDE45E4B928830EEFA0DB21.description: Record and compare observable physical properties (e.g., colour, taste, smell, shape, texture, transparency, and ability to adapt to the shape of container) of familiar liquids and solids.

8AD543A43218443693C1AB00CB8EB00E.description: Select and safely use materials and tools (e.g., magnifier, scale, measuring cup, and spatula) to carry out explorations of the observable physical properties of familiar liquids and solids.

CBAF7CC5F3AD4F349B91B0F48276835F.description: Interpret safety symbols (e.g., WHMIS and consumer chemical hazard symbols) and labels that are used on hazardous product containers for liquids and solids.

29A960628FAC4E86A766AB07EC28C913.description: Identify examples of how liquids, in all three states of matter, are used at home, in the school, and throughout their communities.

EEA29571E6A44AD68A8C80ED872B1489.description: Classify objects in various natural and constructed environments as liquids or solids.

73EED1B3812C4AD4B5DBD341B70EFD87.description: Pose questions that lead to investigation and exploration of the properties of familiar liquids and solids.

4E6E7B6755E4466F9A5B5EF83EA72A7D.description: Investigate properties (e.g., colour, taste, smell, shape, and texture) of familiar liquids and solids.

6B3C8C6FE90F46B9867A6705C69F9945.description: Discuss the care and handling of wild and domesticated animals (e.g., fish, dog, bird, horse, cow), including keeping animals as pets, housing animals in zoos and aquariums, and identifying careers related to animal care.

CD8DB58104C6408495185BE3B79C2AA0.description: Examine ways in which humans and animals interact with each other (e.g., pet, companionship, transportation guide dog, search and rescue, and providing food), including ways in which animals can cause harm to humans

C4A030E8D8A348119EB2AD8198DC6A3C.description: Analyze ways in which human activities intentionally or unintentionally can help or harm wild and domesticated animals.

58110DCABA0447C280A649463E4B4B3B.description: Assess features of natural (e.g., woodland, stream, grassland, and forest) and constructed (e.g., backyard, zoo, schoolyard, and classroom) environments that support or hinder the health and growth of familiar animals

539C17464FFE4BEF9AB907239F6A997D.description: Examine the importance and sacredness of animals in First Nations, Métis, and other cultures.

8663D243ADD74EE89AC17196C24C8FFF.description: Observe familiar animals in natural (e.g., tree, stream, pond, forest, and beneath a rock) and constructed (e.g., garden, sports field, zoo, aquarium, and city) environments safely and respectfully.

3B54952E4D2B4E24A2EBEABE74A49AE4.description: Predict which animals live in various locations (e.g., tree, underground, nest, cave, water, and soil) within a variety of natural and constructed environments.

6C5BA234C8DE4C11B7BFA92BE8682D83.description: Assess the interdependence of humans and animals in natural and constructed environments.

A52D80755C524A1980C1072CB9E150DA.description: Communicate personal thoughts and feelings related to personal growth and change, including transitions that are celebrated in various cultures.

BE7DB68FBEDF4215862A9F4AA1B5CEEB.description: Compare the food choices and eating habits of various familiar animals as they relate to growth and development.

C0F02B0984C940458E2213C9770E9799.description: Examine the implications of traditional and contemporary food choices and eating habits on human growth and development.

AA4EB2FA3F1C4519BCDE25413930A09D.description: Compare patterns in human growth and development to that of familiar animals.

F2C783D47850439FAFE585F28CA78E16.description: Sequence pictures or illustrations of humans and familiar animals according to stage of life cycle.

0C6BBB969F2A4D609B8478EF7627414C.description: Create representations of changes in the growth and development of humans throughout their life cycle (e.g., baby, preschooler, elementary student, teenager, adult, and elderly person).

467AF1977000457986D7F62C944F10E8.description: Predict ways in which humans change as they grow

B194047602234F4EB1F366B0C2E6327B.description: Pose questions about similarities and differences between animal and human growth.

3F60EF998F7E4C9890153FC226C85C99.description: Compare the growth and development of humans with that of familiar animals.

E884D43AC82A4B37A56FD876DB5BB4C5.description: Design an animal suited for life in a particular environment (real or imaginary) and represent its growth and changes throughout its life cycle.

1D4F31FFA9A746798DA90921ED62437B.description: Predict how big a specific animal will grow based on observed patterns of animal growth and changes.

D08DE748242B4879841CDCD431B10951.description: Create a physical, visual, or dramatic representation of the growth and development of familiar animals during their life cycles.

93FFCF27769A48C58F99AF713B4FF770.description: Analyze which traits (e.g., body size, head size to body ratio, and number of limbs) remain relatively constant and which change in specific animals as they grow and develop.

9FB71A2A225E4D82B0CDB332733A3390.description: Describe the characteristics common to each stage (e.g., birth, youth, adulthood, and old age) of the life cycle of familiar animals (e.g., dog, cat, beaver, frog, fish, bird, ant, wasp, and chicken).

CFFFEAF181BC4C89B72D40EEFC930FF9.description: Compare the length and stages of life cycles of familiar animals

CC34AF7004A74A209B1046EA1A4918CC.description: Recognize the cyclic nature of Mother Earth expressed by the Medicine Wheel, including life cycles and seasonal behaviours of animals.

4A5E17C6D11043A98ECE7721A8ACBC8B.description: Identify the names of the offspring (e.g., cub, pup, calf, kitten, chick, fawn, fingerling, maggot, tadpole, gosling, and infant) of familiar animals.

04CD8E9BF10A43AFB0E45EEACFD2894C.description: Use a variety of resources (e.g., Elder, naturalist, zookeeper, park warden, pet store, books, pictures, and videos) to find information about the life cycles of living things.

1D5464AA8A254462A27C48B57F53E810.description: Pose questions about the growth and development of familiar animals.

21D62CC82BBB49C1852DA966C73DFD08.description: Life Science: Animal Growth and Changes (AN)

8A431586AA5C4B78B1C9C0FA5E6E2472.description: Life Science: Animal Growth and Changes (AN)
